newsitem.title: AUSTRALIA: RTRS-FOCUS-ABS finds Australia jobs distortion.
newsitem.headline: RTRS-FOCUS-ABS finds Australia jobs distortion.

text.p: Australia discovered its labour market was stronger than thought on Thursday when the official statistician said a new survey technique had been depressing estimates of jobs growth.
"The defining characteristic of this downturn has been weakness in the labour market, and now we find it was overstated," said Access Economics analyst Chris Richardson.
The changeover has helped make the jobs market look very flat, but economists say it is now more likely to have a little strength.
The distortion stems from the Australian Bureau of Statistics phasing in telephone interviews for its jobs survey.

Each month since August the bureau has replaced one of its eight panels of 8,000 respondents with a new group interviewed by telephone, and each monthly changeover has pushed down the jobs estimate by 6,000 to 9,000.
With Thursday's December data, five of the eight panels had shifted to telephone interviewing and the bureau said the changeover had depressed its workforce by 30,000 to 45,000.
These lower employment estimates must be reflected in higher unemployment, lower workforce participation or both.

A bureau spokesman said early months of the changeover had found a higher unemployment rate -- as sources told Reuters last month -- but that effect had faded and the employment change was now more likely to show up in participation.
"Our analysis will probably show no statistically significant effect on the unemployment rate," a spokesman said.
"There is evidence emerging that the lower employment will be reflected in a compensating effect on the number of persons in the labour force and consequently on participation."
The issue is not the accuracy of employment levels, since no one knows whether the new method is more or less accurate.
But because they produce different results, changing the methods temporarily changes the reported rates of growth.
Whereas economists and policymakers pay little attention to levels, the rates of change -- how quickly the figures are going up or down -- are crucial influences on economic policy.

The employment estimates as published show just 68,000 new jobs since June -- not enough to meet government forecasts. Adjusting for the changed methodology, employment growth would be 98,000 to 113,000, consistent with Canberra's targets.
"We can now be far more confident that the labour market is, at the least, not deteriorating," Bankers Trust chief economist Chris Caton said in an analysis.
The case for a further interest rates cut, which would be the fourth since the Reserve Bank began easing in July, was now weaker than it had been before Thursday's figures, Caton said.
The bureau estimated the effect of telephone interviewing by comparing its results with those from the old face-to-face interviews during the phase-in period.

In two more months (January and February) the phase-in will be over, the survey having reached the final configuration of seven telephone interview panels plus one done face-to-face to introduce each new set of respondents.
If the results to date persist until the end of the changeover, then the new method will have a final effect of depressing the jobs estimate by 42,000 to 63,000.
The spokesman expected a final estimate of the effect would be somewhere between those two levels.
The bureau would eventually publish that estimate along with the corresponding effects on the unemployment rate and participation, he said.
But even then the bureau will be left with the problem of how to present the changeover effect in its data.
The spokesman said the solution would probably be to adjust all of the old face-to-face data to conform with the new method.
The alternative, hardly acceptable, was to put seven so-called trend breaks into the series at each of the phase-in months, warning readers not compare data before and after.
